THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 2.

GETTING THE MONEY
Mr. Keyser, in an Interview, Tells of
Method of Raising Funds and
Success Achieved.

From the Baltimore Sun.
In an interview, Mr. R. Brent
Keyser, president of the board of
trustees, said:
"In every case in which the endowment and extension committee
has made application for a contribution to its, funds it has presented
the Hopkins need in an elaborately
detailed form, and these statements
are now being carefully studied
by these specialists in philanthropy.
For instance, in the School of Engineering a number of gentlemen
who are indentified with some of
the largest industries in the country
have called in engineers to study
our proposition with them, just the
same as they would do in case a
business investment were offered.
And it is this very careful study of
philanthropic enterprises which
assures the committee that an undertaking such as Johns Hopkins
presents will be accomplished. In
the same way the School of Jurisprudence has been presented to a
group of gentlemen who are
!-Iiaking a careful study of the plan
outlined, which is thoroughly in
advance of anything undertaken in
America today.
. "In soliciting the support of gentlemen who are in no way identified
with Johns Hopkins or with Baltimore, three questions arise. The
* first question is, Why should they
be created at Johns Hopkins?
Secondly, What is the condition of
Johns Hopkins University. And,
thirdly, What is Baltimore going
to do to help?
"In regard to the first question it
has been extremely gratifying to
find that there is a genuine and
Widespread belief in the extreme efficiency of the local University. The
recent reports of the Carnegie Foundation have been so careful to point
out the work of Johns Hopkins in
the advancement of learning that
the belief is general that we offer
superior facilities for the work
planned. In answer to the second
question, it has been made clear
that Johns Hopkins is in a perfectly
sound financial condition, and is
about able to carry on its present
work with its present means, but
new needs are being created every
day and there must be trained men
who are capable of solving the new
problems as they arise, and it is for
Johns Hopkins to undertake to provide these men. It is on this point
that the very careful study is being
made by these specialists in philanthropy to whom our matter has

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 10, 1910.

been turned. In regal to the third
question as to what Baltimore will
do, we have given a detailed statement of what Baltimore has done,
and this has been most impressive.
This is also the best assurance as
to what Baltimore will do when
appealed to in the present campaign."

RHODES EXAMINATIONS
Candidates for Scholarships to Be Examined This Month—Conditions
Imposed on Applicants.

The next qualifying examination
for scholars in the United States
under the Rhodes bequest will be
held October 25 and 26, 1910;
among other places, at this University. The selection of scholars
will be completed before the first of
January, 1911, and the electe -1
scholars will begin residence at Oxford in October of the same year.
The scholarships are of the value
of i300 a year, and are tenable for
three years.
It should be clearly understood
that this examination is not competitive, but simply qualifying, and is
merely intended to give assurance
that every selected scholar is up
to the standard of the first examination (responsions) which the
University of Oxford demands of
all candidates for the B. A. degree.
The Rhodes scholars will be selected from candidates who have
successfully passed this, qualifying
examination. One scholar will be
chosen for each State and Territory
to which scholarships are assigned.
Candidates must be unmarried
and must have been born citizens
of the United States. Those are
eligible who shall have passed their
nineteenth birthday, but shall not
have passed their twenty-fifth
birthday, on October 1st of the year
for which they are elected.
It has been decided that all scholars shall have reached before going
into residence at Oxford, at least
the end of their sophomore or second year work at some recognized
degree-granting university or college of the United States.
Candidates may elect whether
,,they will apply for the scholarship
of the State or Territory in which
they have acquired any large part
of their educational qualification,
or for that of the State or Territory in which they have their ordinary private domicile, home, or residence.
In the examination to be held in
October, 1910, candidates will be
examined in the following subjects:
1. Arithmetic—the whole.
2. Either the elements of algebra; or the elements of geometry.

The question of elective system
vs. rigid curriculum has engaged
the attention of many famous
educators, some of whom have favored the one system and others the
other. But no matter which method
of determining the courses a student is to pursue may be considered
best by those who devote their time
to the study of such matters; no
matter whether the choice of his
studies is to be left to the student
himself, or to be determined by the
Faculty of the institution, or to be
worked out under the control of an
adviser; however, in short, the matter is to be settled, we are strongly
opposed to letting that abominable
invention known as the "Schedule"
intrude itself into the business and
nullify by its veto all the beautiful
arrangements that may be contrived.
The difficulty of conflicts, of
course, presents itself in every college at the opening of the session,
but at few, if any, others does it
present such an insurmountable
difficulty to those who wish to avail
themselves of their constitutional
privilege of electing the courses

they are to follow, as at Hopkins.
The reason is not far to seek.
All the lectures and recitations
in the usual courses pursued by undergraduates are crammed into
twenty hours a week, with the result that there are at any given hour
from eight to a dozen classes in session. The partial schedule published in the "Collegiate Instruction" pamphlet shows an average
of a little less than eight different
classes for each hour from nine until one, five days a week. When the
large number of courses whose
hours are not included in this diagram is taken into consideration, it
may seem how seriously the privilege of choosing his own electives
is abridged for the Hopkins undergraduate. Moreover, a single conflict is nearly always sufficient to
prevent a man from following the
course that contains it, and such
single conflicts are far more frequent than complete coincidence of
hours on the part of two courses.
That the present schedule is an
excellent one, in view of the difficulties involved in its arrangement,
we have no doubt. The endless
pains and care taken to make it
produce the least trouble to the
greatest number are to be commended. The difficulty is one that
can only be overcome, in our judgment, by increasing the number of
possible lecture hours. Almost any
little freshwater college with onethird the number of courses given
here would have thirty possible lecture hours a week. We realize that
to make a change in the same direction in our own collegiate department would rouse some opposition,
both reasonable and otherwise; but
we believe that the problem is sufficiently important to make some
sacrifices for a satisfactory solution
worth while.

A controversy has recently been
raging in the newspapers in regard
to the value of allowing patrons
of public libraries access to the
shelves, as compared with the increased loss and expense to the library that such a plan involves.
Whether or not such a system is
practicable for large free libraries,
we are not concerned with here. We
wish, rather, to call the attention of
new students to the fact that they
are allowed this privilege in the
University library and to urge them
to make the most of it. To familiarize oneself with such an admirable collection of books as is here
placed at his disposal, if only by
the study of the outer covers, is a
duty that will also become a pleasure to anyone whose tastes are
even the least inclined toward the
great field of literature.
Homilies on the value of reading
and the pleasures of the booklover
may well be dispensed with here;
but the cry for closer acquaintance
with the public library shelves
ought to remind the undergraduate
of the privilege he enjoys in this
regard, and to encourage him to
make the most of it.

Neither side scored in the third

Fulton failed to kick goal. With
but a few minutes left to play Hopkins again advanced the pigskin
down the gridiron, and victory
seemed assured. When within
striking distance, Schrieber ran to
side lines, and gave Manager
Haynes a tooth which had just been
knocked out of his mouth. He did
not say a word to anybody, and
nothing was said to him, but Referee Hunter penalized the Black
and Blue ten yards. As a last resort Stonie decided to try a drop
kick. When he signaled for the
ball to be passed Woods, who had
been placed at center in McCabe's
place, rolled it along the ground.
The time was up a few minutes
later.
Dick McCabe played a great
game at center until he was hurt,
and even then he was unwilling to
be taken out. "If" he had been
allowed to finish the game, Hopkins might have won as Stonie always responds when his team is in
a pinch. More players like McCabe
are badly needed in the line. Musser's tackling was one of the prettiest features of the game to anyone
who understands football. Time
and again he broke through the
Aggies line and downed the player
with the ball. Shipley was the star
for the Aggies. He is one of the
best players the Agricultural College has ever turned out, and as a
gridiron general showed up most
favorably. The Farmers' team is
much stronger than last year.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES
A meeting will be held today
(Monday) in Levering'Hall at one
o'clock for organizing the Bible
class work for the year. Those who
have arranged the meeting are very
anxious for all who can possibly do
so to be present and lend their
support to the inauguration of the
classes.
The attendance at Friday night's
reception was among the largest on
record. Those two hundred and
fifty harlequin blocks didn't last
long enough to begin to melt.
Levering Hall promises to be
overworked today at one o'clock.
Besides the Bible class organization meeting, there will be a conference of those who desire to form
an Arbitration Society and the first
regular meeting of THE NEWSLETTER Board.
Remember that you can help out
the Y. M. C. A. handbook by getting one of those fountain pens
that Secretary Holmes wants to dispose of in order to realize on an advertising contract.
Some rather remarkable compliments were paid "Chick" Hering
for the excellence of his remarks
at the reception. All who heard him
were impressed with his earnestness
and directness.
The reception to be given by the
Medical School branch of the Y. M.
C. A. to the new students, which
had been announced for Thursday
of last week has been postponed
for unavoidable reasons to the coming Thursday, October 13.

Hopkins Hall was packed to the
doors on Thursday, at one o'clock,
when the first football mass-meeting
of the season was held. Chief
Coach Lynn was present and told
the students what the prospects of
the team were. Dr. Magoffin, John
M. Holmes and several others made
speeches.
Mr. Lynn said that the men who
are out for the team are working
hard, that there is plenty of good
material already developed, and
other material which can be developed with a little practice. "But
the team," he said, "needs the support of the whole undergraduate
body. It needs those men who
have played football; their duty is
to come out and help make the
team a winning one by playing in
the scrubs. I believe that a man
who tries for the varsity and makes
the scrubs, but plays hard on them
and serves as a buffer for the varsity men in their efforts to get experience and training, is just as
much a hero as the lucky man who
runs 70 yards and makes the winning score in the last two minutes
of a championship game."
Dr. Magoffin spoke of the value
of football as a collegiate asset,
and scouted the idea that it should
be abandoned on account of the injuries which have resulted in the
past few years. He said that there
were more automobile accidents in
a Week than football accidents in a
month, a'nd yet no one cried out for
the abolition of the fizz wmon,
while the opponents of football
were legion. Such, he said, was
one of the frailities of human nature.
• "Johnny" Holmes also spoke,and
when his oration was concluded a
short yell practice was held.

Scrubs Arrange Game.

D. K. Belt has been appointed
manager of the Varsity Scrubs, and
he is arranging games for Saturday mornings. This coming Saturday the Country School is scheduled for a game at Homewood, and
November 12, the St. Johns Scrubs
will come up to the field from Annapolis. On November 5, when the
first team will be at Haverford, the
Scrubs will play their game in the
afternoon, probably with either
City College or Polytechnic. It is
to be hoped that the students will
show their appreciation of the hard
work and sacrifices made by the
Scrubs by turning out in goodly
numbers to their games. Season
tickets will admit one free, but
twenty-five cents will be charged
to outsiders.

During the summer months a
great many changes took place at
the University. There were changes
in the Faculty, but these were
merely nominal. There were, however, two great changes which will
seriously affect the undergraduates
—one for better and the other for
worse.
In the former case, the students
found that a new elevator had been
installed—an elevator of the modern type. Hence the danger of getting stuck between two floors and
incurring the wrath of "the powers
that be" is now eliminated.
But, alas! the other change was
a sad one. Walter's barber shop

VOL. XV, NO. 2.

GETTING THE MONEY
Mr. Keyser, in an Interview, Tells of
Method of Raising Funds and
Success Achieved.

From the Baltimore Sun.
In an interview, Mr. R. Brent
Keyser, president of the board of
trustees, said:
"In every case in which the endowment and extension committee
has made application for a contribution to its, funds it has presented
the Hopkins need in an elaborately
detailed form, and these statements
are now being carefully studied
by these specialists in philanthropy.
For instance, in the School of Engineering a number of gentlemen
who are indentified with some of
the largest industries in the country
have called in engineers to study
our proposition with them, just the
same as they would do in case a
business investment were offered.
And it is this very careful study of
philanthropic enterprises which
assures the committee that an undertaking such as Johns Hopkins
presents will be accomplished. In
the same way the School of Jurisprudence has been presented to a
group of gentlemen who are
!-Iiaking a careful study of the plan
outlined, which is thoroughly in
advance of anything undertaken in
America today.
. "In soliciting the support of gentlemen who are in no way identified
with Johns Hopkins or with Baltimore, three questions arise. The
* first question is, Why should they
be created at Johns Hopkins?
Secondly, What is the condition of
Johns Hopkins University. And,
thirdly, What is Baltimore going
to do to help?
"In regard to the first question it
has been extremely gratifying to
find that there is a genuine and
Widespread belief in the extreme efficiency of the local University. The
recent reports of the Carnegie Foundation have been so careful to point
out the work of Johns Hopkins in
the advancement of learning that
the belief is general that we offer
superior facilities for the work
planned. In answer to the second
question, it has been made clear
that Johns Hopkins is in a perfectly
sound financial condition, and is
about able to carry on its present
work with its present means, but
new needs are being created every
day and there must be trained men
who are capable of solving the new
problems as they arise, and it is for
Johns Hopkins to undertake to provide these men. It is on this point
that the very careful study is being
made by these specialists in philanthropy to whom our matter has

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 10, 1910.

been turned. In regal to the third
question as to what Baltimore will
do, we have given a detailed statement of what Baltimore has done,
and this has been most impressive.
This is also the best assurance as
to what Baltimore will do when
appealed to in the present campaign."

RHODES EXAMINATIONS
Candidates for Scholarships to Be Examined This Month—Conditions
Imposed on Applicants.

The next qualifying examination
for scholars in the United States
under the Rhodes bequest will be
held October 25 and 26, 1910;
among other places, at this University. The selection of scholars
will be completed before the first of
January, 1911, and the electe -1
scholars will begin residence at Oxford in October of the same year.
The scholarships are of the value
of i300 a year, and are tenable for
three years.
It should be clearly understood
that this examination is not competitive, but simply qualifying, and is
merely intended to give assurance
that every selected scholar is up
to the standard of the first examination (responsions) which the
University of Oxford demands of
all candidates for the B. A. degree.
The Rhodes scholars will be selected from candidates who have
successfully passed this, qualifying
examination. One scholar will be
chosen for each State and Territory
to which scholarships are assigned.
Candidates must be unmarried
and must have been born citizens
of the United States. Those are
eligible who shall have passed their
nineteenth birthday, but shall not
have passed their twenty-fifth
birthday, on October 1st of the year
for which they are elected.
It has been decided that all scholars shall have reached before going
into residence at Oxford, at least
the end of their sophomore or second year work at some recognized
degree-granting university or college of the United States.
Candidates may elect whether
,,they will apply for the scholarship
of the State or Territory in which
they have acquired any large part
of their educational qualification,
or for that of the State or Territory in which they have their ordinary private domicile, home, or residence.
In the examination to be held in
October, 1910, candidates will be
examined in the following subjects:
1. Arithmetic—the whole.
2. Either the elements of algebra; or the elements of geometry.

The question of elective system
vs. rigid curriculum has engaged
the attention of many famous
educators, some of whom have favored the one system and others the
other. But no matter which method
of determining the courses a student is to pursue may be considered
best by those who devote their time
to the study of such matters; no
matter whether the choice of his
studies is to be left to the student
himself, or to be determined by the
Faculty of the institution, or to be
worked out under the control of an
adviser; however, in short, the matter is to be settled, we are strongly
opposed to letting that abominable
invention known as the "Schedule"
intrude itself into the business and
nullify by its veto all the beautiful
arrangements that may be contrived.
The difficulty of conflicts, of
course, presents itself in every college at the opening of the session,
but at few, if any, others does it
present such an insurmountable
difficulty to those who wish to avail
themselves of their constitutional
privilege of electing the courses

they are to follow, as at Hopkins.
The reason is not far to seek.
All the lectures and recitations
in the usual courses pursued by undergraduates are crammed into
twenty hours a week, with the result that there are at any given hour
from eight to a dozen classes in session. The partial schedule published in the "Collegiate Instruction" pamphlet shows an average
of a little less than eight different
classes for each hour from nine until one, five days a week. When the
large number of courses whose
hours are not included in this diagram is taken into consideration, it
may seem how seriously the privilege of choosing his own electives
is abridged for the Hopkins undergraduate. Moreover, a single conflict is nearly always sufficient to
prevent a man from following the
course that contains it, and such
single conflicts are far more frequent than complete coincidence of
hours on the part of two courses.
That the present schedule is an
excellent one, in view of the difficulties involved in its arrangement,
we have no doubt. The endless
pains and care taken to make it
produce the least trouble to the
greatest number are to be commended. The difficulty is one that
can only be overcome, in our judgment, by increasing the number of
possible lecture hours. Almost any
little freshwater college with onethird the number of courses given
here would have thirty possible lecture hours a week. We realize that
to make a change in the same direction in our own collegiate department would rouse some opposition,
both reasonable and otherwise; but
we believe that the problem is sufficiently important to make some
sacrifices for a satisfactory solution
worth while.

A controversy has recently been
raging in the newspapers in regard
to the value of allowing patrons
of public libraries access to the
shelves, as compared with the increased loss and expense to the library that such a plan involves.
Whether or not such a system is
practicable for large free libraries,
we are not concerned with here. We
wish, rather, to call the attention of
new students to the fact that they
are allowed this privilege in the
University library and to urge them
to make the most of it. To familiarize oneself with such an admirable collection of books as is here
placed at his disposal, if only by
the study of the outer covers, is a
duty that will also become a pleasure to anyone whose tastes are
even the least inclined toward the
great field of literature.
Homilies on the value of reading
and the pleasures of the booklover
may well be dispensed with here;
but the cry for closer acquaintance
with the public library shelves
ought to remind the undergraduate
of the privilege he enjoys in this
regard, and to encourage him to
make the most of it.

kick. Stollenwerck caught the
punt on his 37-yard line and made

Neither side scored in the third
session of play. Bridgeman was
put in Riley's place in the back field
and he and Pieper alternated in
tearing through the Aggies in the
fourth quarter. Hopkins advanced
steadily down the field with the
prolate spheroid, and Pieper carried
it over the line, tying the score
Fulton failed to kick goal. With
but a few minutes left to play Hopkins again advanced the pigskin
down the gridiron, and victory
seemed assured. When within
striking distance, Schrieber ran to
side lines, and gave Manager
Haynes a tooth which had just been
knocked out of his mouth. He did
not say a word to anybody, and
nothing was said to him, but Referee Hunter penalized the Black
and Blue ten yards. As a last resort Stonie decided to try a drop
kick. When he signaled for the
ball to be passed Woods, who had
been placed at center in McCabe's
place, rolled it along the ground.
The time was up a few minutes
later.
Dick McCabe played a great
game at center until he was hurt,
and even then he was unwilling to
be taken out. "If" he had been
allowed to finish the game, Hopkins might have won as Stonie always responds when his team is in
a pinch. More players like McCabe
are badly needed in the line. Musser's tackling was one of the prettiest features of the game to anyone
who understands football. Time
and again he broke through the
Aggies line and downed the player
with the ball. Shipley was the star
for the Aggies. He is one of the
best players the Agricultural College has ever turned out, and as a
gridiron general showed up most
favorably. The Farmers' team is
much stronger than last year.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES
A meeting will be held today
(Monday) in Levering'Hall at one
o'clock for organizing the Bible
class work for the year. Those who
have arranged the meeting are very
anxious for all who can possibly do
so to be present and lend their
support to the inauguration of the
classes.
The attendance at Friday night's
reception was among the largest on
record. Those two hundred and
fifty harlequin blocks didn't last
long enough to begin to melt.
Levering Hall promises to be
overworked today at one o'clock.
Besides the Bible class organization meeting, there will be a conference of those who desire to form
an Arbitration Society and the first
regular meeting of THE NEWSLETTER Board.
Remember that you can help out
the Y. M. C. A. handbook by getting one of those fountain pens
that Secretary Holmes wants to dispose of in order to realize on an advertising contract.
Some rather remarkable compliments were paid "Chick" Hering
for the excellence of his remarks
at the reception. All who heard him
were impressed with his earnestness
and directness.
The reception to be given by the
Medical School branch of the Y. M.
C. A. to the new students, which
had been announced for Thursday
of last week has been postponed
for unavoidable reasons to the coming Thursday, October 13.

Hopkins Hall was packed to the
doors on Thursday, at one o'clock,
when the first football mass-meeting
of the season was held. Chief
Coach Lynn was present and told
the students what the prospects of
the team were. Dr. Magoffin, John
M. Holmes and several others made
speeches.
Mr. Lynn said that the men who
are out for the team are working
hard, that there is plenty of good
material already developed, and
other material which can be developed with a little practice. "But
the team," he said, "needs the support of the whole undergraduate
body. It needs those men who
have played football; their duty is
to come out and help make the
team a winning one by playing in
the scrubs. I believe that a man
who tries for the varsity and makes
the scrubs, but plays hard on them
and serves as a buffer for the varsity men in their efforts to get experience and training, is just as
much a hero as the lucky man who
runs 70 yards and makes the winning score in the last two minutes
of a championship game."
Dr. Magoffin spoke of the value
of football as a collegiate asset,
and scouted the idea that it should
be abandoned on account of the injuries which have resulted in the
past few years. He said that there
were more automobile accidents in
a Week than football accidents in a
month, a'nd yet no one cried out for
the abolition of the fizz wmon,
while the opponents of football
were legion. Such, he said, was
one of the frailities of human nature.
• "Johnny" Holmes also spoke,and
when his oration was concluded a
short yell practice was held.

Scrubs Arrange Game.

D. K. Belt has been appointed
manager of the Varsity Scrubs, and
he is arranging games for Saturday mornings. This coming Saturday the Country School is scheduled for a game at Homewood, and
November 12, the St. Johns Scrubs
will come up to the field from Annapolis. On November 5, when the
first team will be at Haverford, the
Scrubs will play their game in the
afternoon, probably with either
City College or Polytechnic. It is
to be hoped that the students will
show their appreciation of the hard
work and sacrifices made by the
Scrubs by turning out in goodly
numbers to their games. Season
tickets will admit one free, but

During the summer months a
great many changes took place at
the University. There were changes
in the Faculty, but these were
merely nominal. There were, however, two great changes which will
seriously affect the undergraduates
—one for better and the other for
worse.
In the former case, the students
found that a new elevator had been
installed—an elevator of the modern type. Hence the danger of getting stuck between two floors and
incurring the wrath of "the powers
that be" is now eliminated.
But, alas! the other change was
a sad one. Walter's barber shop
—a time-honored place of gathering, a place for hanging one's hat,
a place for keeping one's books—
